      void refreshArmaturePins()
      If you have created some sort of save / load system for your armatures which might make it difficult to notify the armature when a pin has been enabled on a bone, you can call this function after all bones and pins have been instantiated and associated with one another to index all of the pins on the armature.

      • updateArmatureSegments

        public void updateArmatureSegments()
        this method should be called whenever a bone in this armature has been pinned or unpinned. for the most part, the abstract classes call this when necessary. But if you are extending classes more than you would reasonably expect this library to reasonably expect and getting weird results, you might try calling this method after making any substantial structural changes to the armature.

      • refreshArmaturePins

        public void refreshArmaturePins()
        If you have created some sort of save / load system for your armatures which might make it difficult to notify the armature when a pin has been enabled on a bone, you can call this function after all bones and pins have been instantiated and associated with one another to index all of the pins on the armature.

      • IKSolver

        public void IKSolver​(AbstractBone bone)
        automatically solves the IK system of this armature from the given bone using the armature's default IK parameters. You can specify these using the setDefaultIterations() setDefaultIKType() and setDefaultDampening() methods. The library comes with some defaults already set, so you can more or less use this method out of the box if you're just testing things out.
        Parameters:
        bone -

      • IKSolver

        public void IKSolver​(AbstractBone bone,
                     double dampening,
                     int iterations)

      • ambitiousIKSolver

        public void ambitiousIKSolver​(AbstractBone bone)
        Same as other ambitiousIKSolver method, but uses the armature's default iteration and dampening.
        Parameters:
        bone -

      • ambitiousIKSolver

        public void ambitiousIKSolver​(AbstractBone bone,
                              double dampening,
                              int iterations)
        This solver aims to minimize the total distance to the target pins, however if the pins are impossible to reach AND the armature is under-constrained, this solver can become unstable. That said, it is quite stable when the chain armature is sufficiently constrained. That is -- it is stable if you constrain all bones affected by the solver with Kusudamas such that full 360 degree rotations on any axis are disallowed.
        Parameters:
        bone - the bone from which to begin solving the IK system. Pinned ancestors of this bone will not be modifed. Pinned children will however, will also have this solver called on them, recursively.
        dampening - the maximum number of radians any bone is allowed to rotate per iteration. a lower number gives more evenly distributed results, but may take a larger number of iterations before it converges on a solution. if you don't know what you want, try starting with 0.1.
        iterations - the number of times to run the IK loop before returning an answer.

      • solveIK

      • tranquilIKSolver

        Same as other tranquilIKSolver method, but uses the armature's default iteration and dampening.
        Parameters:
        bone -

      • tranquilIKSolver

        public void tranquilIKSolver​(AbstractBone bone,
                             double dampening,
                             int iterations)
        Highly stable even when under-constrained, and also when over-constrained (by Kusudamas) Converges on a solution satisfying all pins and constraints where possible. converges on something that looks like a polite but not especially strenuous effort at reaching the target pins when impossible. This solver is good if you care more about stability than minimizing total distance to target pins. IKchain is solved starting from the current bone, and traveling rootward until a pinned bone is encountered. If the entire armature only contains one pin, the entire armature gets translated to meet the requirements of that pin.
        Parameters:
        bone - the bone from which to begin solving the IK system. Pinned ancestors of this bone will not be modifed. Pinned children will however have this solver called on them -- recursively.
        dampening - the maximum number of radians any bone is allowed to rotate per iteration. a lower number gives more evenly distributed results, but may take a larger number of iterations before it converges on a solution. if you don't know what you want, try starting with 0.1.
        iterations - the number of times to run the IK loop before returning an answer.

      • alternateIKSolver

        protected void alternateIKSolver​(StrandedArmature collection,
                                 double dampening,
                                 int iterations)

      • localAxes

        public AbstractAxes localAxes()
        Returns:
        a reference to the Axes serving as this Armature's coordinate system.

      • orientationAwareIKSolver

        public void orientationAwareIKSolver​(AbstractBone bone,
                                     double dampening,
                                     int iterations)
        Experimental. AmbitiousIKSolver and TranquilIKSolver only try to satisfy end-effector position. This solver attempts to satisfy end effector orientation as well. As an example of the difference between this solver and the other two -- with this solver, you can cause a humanoid rig's palm to remain flat against a spot on wall. Whereas with the other two solvers, doing this would require multiple pins orthogonal bones. While this method should offer results similar to using multiple pins, it has the advantage of allowing you to specify how much you care about orientation vs position. Attempts to satisfy even orientational targets of end effectors.
        Parameters:
        bone - the bone from which to begin solving the IK system. Pinned ancestors of this bone will not be modifed. Pinned children will however have this solver called on them -- recursively.
        dampening - the maximum number of radians any bone is allowed to rotate per iteration. a lower number gives more evenly distributed results, but may take a larger number of iterations before it converges on a solution. if you don't know what you want, try starting with 0.1.
        iterations - the number of times to run the IK loop before returning an answer.

      • orientationIKSolver

        protected void orientationIKSolver​(StrandedArmature collection,
                                   double dampening,
                                   int iterations)

      • fabriCCDIKSolver

        public void fabriCCDIKSolver​(AbstractBone bone,
                             double dampening,
                             int iterations)
        FabriCCD outline-- basic idea: take the tip of each strand and position and orient it in accordance with its end effector. start currentBone sequence take the parent bone of the currentBone, point it to the currentBone's base, then translate its tip to that base. snap the currentBone to its constraints. call the REPAIR TIP function the exact repair tip procedure should be modular so I can experiment -- but some ideas include 1. simply rotate from the base of the parent bone in the strand tip -> strand target direction (CCD like). 2. do another Forward Fabrik pass from this configuration. do a backward fabrik iteration

      • fabriCCDSolver

        protected void fabriCCDSolver​(StrandedArmature collection,
                              double dampening,
                              int iterations)
